hitch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to get free rides from the drivers of passing cars by standing at the side of the road and putting a hand out with the thumb raised
hitch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: We hitched a ride with a trucker.
He plans to hitch right round the coast of Ireland.
hitch.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move a piece of clothing you are wearing so that it is higher than it was before
hitch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She hitched her skirt above her knees and knelt down.
hitch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to lift yourself into a higher position by pushing with your hands
hitch.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Gail hitched herself up onto the high stool.
hitch.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to fasten something to something else, using a rope, chain etc
hitch.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: He hitched our pick-up to his trailer.
a goat hitched to a fence
hitch.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to fasten an animal to something with wheels so that the animal can pull it forwards
hitch.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I hitched up the horse and drove out into the fields.
hitch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a small problem that makes something difficult or delays it for a short time
hitch.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The whole show went without a hitch.
In spite of some technical hitches, the first program was a success.
hitch.translation[1].definitions[0].note: In written English, people usually prefer to use (small/minor) problem rather than hitch, which sounds slightly informal:
There were some minor technical problems when the product was first released.
